results.title: High renaissance
results.creator_credit: Geoff Dunlop and Educational Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Art of the western world”.
An episode in the comprehensive art history series, “Art of the Western World”, that focuses on art work from Classical and Renaissance Italy. Narrated by Michael Wood, this program focuses on the readaption of the classical style in works by Titian and Tintoretto and the Renaissance works of such artists as Leonardo Da Vinci, Michelangelo and Raphael. Through a discussion of the works in their historical, religious, intellectual and social context this program provides both a thorough outline of these periods in art history and underlines their relevance to issues outside the parameters of the works themselves.

results.title: Realms of light: the baroque
results.creator_credit: Eugene Marner, Carole Lucia Satrina and Educational Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Art of the western world”.
An episode in the comprehensive art history series, “Art of the Western World”, that focuses on art work from the commissions arising from the church’s campaign against the Reformation to works commissioned by the Royal and wealthy of Europe in the 17th century. Narrated by Michael Wood, this program focuses on dramatic depictions of religious scenes in the work of Caravaggio and Bernini as well as the work of such artists as Velazquez and Rembrandt. Through a discussion of the works in their historical, religious, intellectual and social context this program provides both a thorough outline of these periods in art history and underlines their relevance to issues outside the parameters of the works themselves.

results.title: Renaissance
results.brief_description: Explores the Renaissance, a turbulent 300 year period that gave rise to ideas and issues that transformed European culture and have shaped the modern world. In six parts, this series looks at the Renaissance from the perspective of the archetypal figures of the age.
results.description: Explores the Renaissance, a turbulent 300 year period that gave rise to ideas and issues that transformed European culture and have shaped the modern world. In six parts, this series looks at the Renaissance from the perspective of the archetypal figures of the age.

results.title: A World reborn
results.creator_credit: Bill Jersey and Barr Media Group
results.brief_description:
Episode number 6 of Series “Renaissance”.
Presents an excellent overview of history and contribution of the Renaissance. Traces the 300 years of this age from the early ideas of pioneers such as Petrach and Jan Hus, who sparked new ways of thinking, to innovators like Brunelleschi and Maciavelli, to the artistic, scientific and political revolutions of the High Renaissance, to the years when Europe finally accepted a vision of the world that was changed forever.

results.title: The Dissenter
results.creator_credit: Bill Jersey and Barr Media Group
results.brief_description:
Episode number 5 of Series “Renaissance”.
This program documents the lives and ideas of dissenters who suffered death and/or excommunication in their challenge to the power of the Church. Through dramatic re-enactments you meet Jan Hus, John Wyclif, Martin Luther, Argula Von Grumbach, and others who questioned established authority. The essence of dissent is captured through interviews with modern day dissenters fighting orthodoxy.

results.title: The Warrior
results.creator_credit: Lee R. Bobker, Helen Kirstt Radin and Barr Media Group
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “Renaissance”.
This thought-provoking presentation documents how the advent of gunpowder during the Renaissance brought about drastic changes in our perception of war and warriors. Beginning with the medieval knight, the glorious warrior, we see how this noble image was forever lost with the development of grander, more mechanised warfare. This program captures the new horrors of war and emphasises the relevancy of the issues during the Renaissance through interviews with contemporary experts in the field of international warfare.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Lee R. Bobker, Helen Kirstt Radin and Barr Media Group

results.title: The Scientist
results.creator_credit: Lee R. Bobker, Helen Kirstt Radin and Barr Media Group
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Renaissance”.
Of the profound changes that occured during the Renaissance, none shaped the modern world more than the emergence of science. This program documents the age through a study of the lives and works the scientists such Paracelsus, Copernicus, Kepler, Galileo and others who struggled to create a new vision of the world - a vision still evolving as we learn from interviews with today’s scientists.

results.title: The Prince
results.creator_credit: Bill Jersey and Barr Media Group
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Renaissance”.
Documents the lives and accomplishments of the “Princes” of the Renaissance. Discover the motivations and political solutions of leaders such as Cosimo di Medici, Prince Philip of Spain and Queen Elizabeth of England. Learn about Machiavelli, a maligned political theorist, but one of the most influential figures in the politics of his age. Furthermore, explore the Renaissance leaders legacy that continues to influence today’s statesmen.

results.title: The Artist
results.creator_credit: Lee R. Bobker, Helen Kirstt Radin and Barr Media Group
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Renaissance”.
This outstanding production documents the Renaissance through a study of lives and works of the artists who gave meaning to creative expression. Discover the triumph and trials of Brunelleschi, Leonardo Da Vinci, Michelangelo and other masters. Review the movement of persons from craftsmen to artists and the challenge to unwarranted control by the guilds, the church and affluent patrons. Finally, examine the currency of these issues through interviews with contemporary artists.

results.title: The Developing image
results.creator_credit: David Hopwood and Northern Virginia Community College. Extended Learning Institute
results.brief_description: Explores the marvellous invention of the camera, using colour and music to evoke the period. This series takes viewers from the daguerreotype to wet plate to tintype and onwards examining hundreds of exemplary photographs. It dramatically depicts various themes in the history of photography.
